since_last_update: Dominant tape shift: AI-capex “show-me” skepticism intensified after Amazon guided ~50%+ higher 2026 capex (~$200B), reinforcing the broader Magnificent Seven spend-spree narrative that has been pressuring tech duration/valuation (Reuters, Investopedia).

Cross-asset backdrop leaned risk-defensive earlier in the week: software/tech weakness + softer labor signals (job-cut announcements, higher initial claims) supported a rally in Treasuries and a steeper curve, consistent with the market leaning more into 2026 Fed cuts (WA Trust weekly review).

Friday saw a partial risk rebound (broad equities up; tech stabilization) even as Amazon sold off—suggesting positioning/relief-rally dynamics rather than a clean fundamental all-clear for mega-cap capex ROI (AP, Barron’s).
Gold futures participation cooled into Friday (lower volume/open interest vs prior day), consistent with a market that has been volatile and sensitive to real-rate and risk-sentiment swings (AP).

Consumer sentiment improved modestly in early-Feb Michigan survey; 1-year inflation expectations fell while longer-run expectations edged up—keeps the ‘policy credibility vs growth slowdown’ mix in play for rates and gold correlations (WSJ).
today_focus: Primary driver check (today/session): AI-capex/tech-duration repricing remains the dominant equity narrative (especially Nasdaq) with spillover into index breadth (software vs semi/AI infrastructure winners) (Reuters, Barron’s).

Rates channel: the market is increasingly sensitive to front-end repricing toward 2026 cuts (curve steepening) on any incremental labor softening—supportive for long-duration equities on yields down, but fragile if inflation expectations re-accelerate (WA Trust weekly review, WSJ).

Gold focus: direction likely to be dictated by real-yield impulses and risk hedging demand; correlations may be unstable given simultaneous ‘Fed cuts’ and ‘inflation expectations’ cross-currents (WSJ, AP).

Weekend/low-liquidity risk: with the prior week featuring sharp factor rotations (defensives vs tech) and elevated narrative uncertainty, gap risk into next week’s data/earnings remains non-trivial (inference; supported by Reuters/Barron’s describing volatile week and tech rout/relief).

equities.pricing_summary: Index level appears to be pricing a tug-of-war between (1) a continuing mega-cap/AI capex valuation compression (negative for NQ concentration) and (2) easier financial conditions via lower yields if growth data softens (supportive for ES breadth on dips).
what_is_priced: Near-term earnings reactions increasingly hinge on capex intensity/ROI visibility (AI spend without monetization discount) (Reuters, Investopedia).

Higher dispersion within tech: AI infrastructure/semis can catch bid on spend-through while software/SaaS remains vulnerable to ‘AI disruption + multiple compression’ framing (Reuters, Barron’s; inference consistent with cited coverage).
what_may_be_underpriced: Second-order drag: capex escalation can pressure free cash flow optics across multiple mega-caps simultaneously, raising index-level concentration risk if multiple Mag7 names re-rate together (inference; supported by Reuters/Barron’s capex focus).

If long-run inflation expectations firm further, the market may be underpricing a regime where yields don’t fall much even if growth softens—bad for both NQ and gold simultaneously (inference; supported by WSJ expectations mix).

rates.pricing_summary: Narrative consistent with increasing confidence in multiple 2026 cuts (front-end yields down; curve steeper) driven by softer labor signals and risk-off flows earlier in the week (WA Trust weekly review).
what_is_priced: Greater probability of at least two Fed cuts in 2026 and earlier timing than previously assumed (WA Trust weekly review).
what_may_be_underpriced: Term premium/fiscal risk can reassert and cap the downside in long-end yields even if front-end rallies—risk of curve volatility (inference; consistent with WA Trust noting term premium/fiscal concerns).

gold.pricing_summary: Gold is trading as a hybrid: (a) beneficiary of risk hedging during tech-led drawdowns and (b) sensitive to real-rate and inflation-expectations swings; positioning/participation signals show volatility with some cooling after the week’s moves (AP, WSJ).
what_is_priced: Ongoing two-way risk around inflation expectations (1y down but longer-run edging higher) keeping gold responsive to macro prints/surveys (WSJ).
what_may_be_underpriced: Correlation instability risk: gold may not hedge equities cleanly if the shock is ‘higher long-run inflation expectations’ that lifts real yields or USD (inference; anchored by WSJ expectations signal).

risk_register.risk: AI-capex shock broadens into sustained tech-duration de-rating (multiple compression + FCF optics), pulling NQ/ES via concentration even if economic data is mixed.
Rates whipsaw: growth-slowdown data pushes yields down (supports equities) but any rebound in longer-run inflation expectations reverses the move, hitting NQ and destabilizing gold hedging behavior.
Labor-data uncertainty/processing risk after recent disruptions (delays/revisions) increases the chance of a sharp repricing in front-end rates on release day.
Systematic/positioning air-pockets: high dispersion and rapid factor rotations elevate the risk of liquidity-driven extensions (both directions) around key prints/mega-cap headlines.
risk_register.timeframe: Ongoing; highest around major data/earnings days

risk_register.risk: Gold market volatility transmits into broader VAR/margin dynamics (forced selling) if macro shock causes simultaneous equity and precious-metals drawdown.

event_warnings: Key near-term macro catalysts next week: January jobs report and CPI are flagged as major focuses for the coming week (Barron’s).

Labor-market print timing risk: multiple sources indicate the January employment report was delayed and expected mid-week (not on the usual Friday schedule), elevating gap/vol risk around release timing (WA Trust weekly review).

Earnings remain a volatility catalyst: market is reacting not just to beats/misses but to 2026 capex guidance and monetization commentary—expect outsized single-name and index-factor swings on mega-cap updates (Reuters, Investopedia).
Inflation expectations watch: any further firming in longer-run expectations (even with 1-year easing) can matter disproportionately for real yields and gold behavior (WSJ).
